TextView.android:text: Gulab Jamun is a very popular Indian sweet. These soft sugar syrup soaked balls are a treat always. Sometimes to satisfy our sweet cravings.

Ingredients-\n\n1 cup khoya or mawa – 200 grams, 100 grams of paneer, 3 tablespoon all purpose flour, 2 tablespoon fine sooji, 4 green cardamoms – powdered or 1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder, 1 tablespoon milk or add as required, 1/4 teaspoon baking powder, Oil for deep frying – as required, 1.75 cups sugar – 250 grams, 1 cup water, 1 tablespoon rose water, 1 tablespoon milk.

Procedure-\n\nStep 1.1 - Making Dough - Take khoya in a bowl. Mash it very well. There should be no lumps. You can also grate and then mash the khoya. Step 1.2 - Then add grated paneer, rava (sooji), all purpose flour , baking powder and cardamom powder to the mashed khoya. There should be no lumps in both the mawa and paneer. Step 1.3 - As if they are there, then you will find the texture of the gulab jamun not so good. The bits and pieces of mava or paneer will give a bite in the mouth, when you have the gulab jamun. They won’t be smooth. Step 1.4 - Mix well. Add milk and gather together to form a dough with milk. Don’t knead.Just gently mix. If you are unable to form balls or if the mixture appears dry, then add a few teaspoons of milk. Cover the dough and keep aside for 30 mins. Step 1.5 - Make small balls from the dough. Cover the balls and keep aside. Step 2.1 - Making Sugar Syrup - Dissolve sugar in water. Heat the sugar solution till it become sticky. You just need to switch off the fire before the syrup reaches a one thread consistency. Step 2.2 - Add rose water and stir. Keep the sugar solution aside. On cooling if the sugar syrup crystallizes, then just add 2 to 3 tbsp water and warm the syrup again. It will again return to a liquid state. Step 3.1 - Frying - Meanwhile, while the sugar syrup is cooking, heat oil till its medium hot. Lower the flame and wait for a minute. Then gently place the dough balls in the oil. Step 3.2 - Once they start to have tiny golden spots, keep on rotating them in the oil, so that the jamun are evenly browned. Step 3.3 - Remove the fried jamun and then drain them on kitchen paper towels to remove excess oil. Step 4.1 - Then place the hot fried dough balls in the sugar syrup. Continue frying the rest of the dough balls in batches. Step 4.2 - When all the jamuns are placed in the sugar syrup, then keep the whole pan with the sugar syrup and the gulab jamun, on a low flame for 1 to 2 minutes till the jamun become soft. Step 4.3 - Heating helps the gulab jamun to absorb the syrup and become soft. The jamun increase a bit in size. Don’t overcook as then the jamun can break. Step 4.4 - Use a large pan, so that the jamuns are not overcrowded and you can easily stir them gently while they are simmering. Step 4.5 - Serve gulab jamun warm. You can also chill them and serve them cold. Garnish with rose petals or almond slivers.
